column1: #Text=MariaDB vs MySQL: [2021] Everything You Need to Know
#Text=The Ultimate MySQL Bootcamp: Go from SQL Beginner to Expert (udemy.com)
#Text=MariaDB vs MySQL: [2021] Everything You Need to Know
#Text=MySQL is one of the most widely used databases across the world.
#Text=It is free and is open-source as well.
#Text=Developed in C/C++, MySQL is one of the most popular database choices.
#Text=The database was started by a Swedish company “MySQL AB” in 1995.
#Text=MySQL AB was later acquired by Sun Microsystems in 2008.
#Text=Later, Sun Microsystems was acquired by Oracle in 2010.
#Text=Since then, MySQL is maintained and managed by Oracle.

#Text=During the acquisition of Sun Microsystems by Oracle, some of the senior engineers who were working on the development of MySQL felt that there is a conflict of interest between MySQL and Oracle’s commercial database - Oracle Database Server.
#Text=As a result, these engineers created a fork of MySQL code base and started their own organization.
#Text=As of today, both databases are highly popular and are extensively used by the developer community.
#Text=MySQL is ranked #2 among the relational databases and #2 overall (#1 being Oracle database).
#Text=On the contrary, MariaDB is slightly behind - #9 among the relational databases and #14 overall.
#Text=In this blog post, we will try to compare some of the features of both of these databases to see which one is the best for usage in 2021.
#Text=MariaDB has several optimizations that tend to improve the performance as compared to MySQL.
#Text=In fact, that was exactly the vision in mind when MariaDB was started by Michael Widenius, the original founder of both MySQL as well as MariaDB.
#Text=As an example, there is a huge performance optimization with respect to database “views”.
#Text=“Views” are essentially virtual database tables which can be queried like regular tables of the database.
#Text=In MySQL, when you query a view, all of the tables that are connected to the view are queried, irrespective of the fact that the query may not require some of the views.
#Text=This has been optimized in MariaDB where only those tables are queried that are required by the query.
#Text=As another example, MariaDB provides yet another powerful performance improvement in the form of “ColumnStore” which is a distributed data architecture that allows scaling MariaDB greatly.
#Text=It can scale linearly to store petabytes of data across various servers in a database cluster.
#Text=MariaDB also provides MyRocks storage engine that adds the RocksDB database to it.
#Text=RocksDB is a database that has been designed for better performance in flash storage by providing a higher level of data compression.
#Text=MariaDB introduces another performance improvement in the form of Segmented Key Cache.
#Text=In a typical cache, various threads compete to take a lock over the cached entry.
#Text=When multiple threads are competing for a mutex, only one of them is able to get it while others have to wait for the lock to get freed before performing the operation.
#Text=This leads to execution delays in these threads slowing down the database performance.
#Text=In case of Segmented Key Cache, the thread need not lock the entire page, but it can lock only the particular segment to which the page belongs.
#Text=This helps multiple threads to work in parallel thereby increasing the parallelism in the application leading to better performance of the database.
#Text=An interesting feature that MariaDB supports is that of virtual columns.
#Text=These columns are capable of performing the calculations at the database level.
#Text=This is extremely useful when many applications are accessing the same column and so, there is no need to write the calculation in each application - the database can do that for you.
#Text=One of the recent versions of MariaDB - 10.0 allows for parallel execution of several queries.
#Text=The idea is that some queries from the Master can be replicated in the slave and can, therefore, be executed in parallel.
#Text=This parallelism in query execution certainly provides MariaDB an edge over MySQL.
#Text=MariaDB also introduces a new concept called “Thread Pooling”.
#Text=Previously, when multiple connections to a database were needed, for each connection, a thread was opened leading to a “one thread per connection” based architecture.
#Text=With “Thread Pooling”, there will be a pool of open threads which a new connection can pick up and query the database.
#Text=This way, a new thread need not be opened for every new connection request leading to faster query results.
#Text=This feature is available in the Enterprise edition of MySQL but is unfortunately unavailable in the Community edition.
#Text=MariaDB provides several powerful storage engines out-of-the-box which are not available in MySQL.
#Text=To set up these storage engines for MySQL, you need to install them manually which may not be the most convenient thing.
#Text=MariaDB team is making sure that MariaDB can seamlessly replace MySQL in the existing applications.
#Text=In fact, for each version of MySQL, they release the same version number of MariaDB to indicate that MariaDB is generally compatible with the corresponding MySQL version.
#Text=This opens up the possibility of switching to MariaDB seamlessly without any modifications in the application code-base.
#Text=MySQL is a large project and is managed by one of the largest organizations in the world - Oracle.
#Text=One of the biggest con is that releasing new features in organizations that big takes a lot of time.
#Text=On the other hand, MariaDB is fully open sourced and they are quite fast in accepting outside contributions and releasing as new features and enhancements.
#Text=This is yet another point that must be kept in mind while deciding between MySQL and MariaDB.
#Text=MariaDB is undoubtedly quite powerful and provides many features that are extremely useful and are not supported in MySQL.
#Text=Such features indeed make MariaDB a lucrative choice to be used as the primary backend database.
#Text=Generally speaking, organizations that have already purchased licenses for Oracle need not invest in MariaDB.
#Text=However, those who are starting afresh and want to decide on which database to use, undoubtedly MariaDB is a better choice.
#Text=Which database you opt for, Hackr.io has programming community-recommended tutorials for both:
#Text=Aman Goel Entrepreneur, Coder, Speed-cuber, Blogger, fan of Air crash investigation!
